Mobile Device Equipment Security Mobile device equipment presents a unique set of security concerns due to their portability. These devices include, but are not limited to:
Mobile Device Equipment
Security
Mobile device equipment presents a unique set
of security concerns due to their portability.
These devices include, but are not limited to:

– Laptops – Portable computers – Personal Digital Assistants (PDA) – Compact Discs (CD) – Digital Video Devices (DVD) – Flash drives
– Laptops – L a p t o p s
– Portable computers – P o r t a b l e
c o m p u t e r s
– Personal Digital Assistants (PDA) – P e r s o n a l
D i g i t a l
A s s i s t a n t s
( P D A )
– Compact Discs (CD) – C o m p a c t
D i s c s
( C D )
– Digital Video Devices (DVD) – D i g i t a l
V i d e o
D e v i c e s
( D V D )
– Flash drives – F l a s h
d r i v e s

Mobile Device Equipment Security
Mobile Device Equipment
Security

Contractors must consider the physical security of these devices and the protection of the confidential and/or sensitive information that is often stored on them.
Contractors must consider the physical
security of these devices and the
protection of the confidential and/or
sensitive information that is often stored
on them.

Mobile Device Equipment Security As a reminder, Contractors are responsible for: • The security of their assigned mobile device equipment and any confidential, sensitive, or personal information (data) that it may contain.

Mobile Device Equipment Guidelines
Mobile Device Equipment
Guidelines

The following guidelines are intended to help improve the protection of mobile device equipment.
The following guidelines are intended to
help improve the protection of mobile
device equipment.

Physical Security of Mobile Devices Do’s and Don’ts
Physical Security of Mobile
Devices
Do’s and Don’ts

• Don’t store your password with your mobile device.
• Don’t store your password with your mobile device. • D o n ’ t
s t o r e
y o u r
p a s s w o r d
w i t h
y o u r
m o b i l e
d e v i c e .

– You should secure your mobile device with a strong password, but don’t keep the password in the carrying case or on a piece of paper attached to the equipment.
– You should secure your mobile device with a strong password,
but don’t keep the password in the carrying case or on a piece
of paper attached to the equipment.

• Don’t leave your mobile device in your car.
• Don’t leave your mobile device in your car. • D o n ’ t
l e a v e
y o u r
m o b i l e

i n
y o u r
c a r .

– Don’t leave your mobile device on the seat or even locked in
– Don’t leave your mobile device on the seat or even locked in

the trunk. Locked cars are often the target of thieves.
the trunk. Locked cars are often the target of thieves.

• Don’t store your mobile in checked luggage.
• Don’t store your mobile in checked luggage. • D o n ’ t
s t o r e
y o u r
m o b i l e
i n
c h e c k e d
l u g g a g e .

– Never store your mobile device in checked luggage. Always
– Never store your mobile device in checked luggage. Always

carry it with you.
carry it with you.

• Don’t carry mobile devices in easily identifiable carrying cases. – Particularly when traveling through airports, mobile devices should be kept in briefcases, backpacks, or other carrying cases that are not obvious.
• Don’t carry mobile devices in easily identifiable carrying cases. • D o n ’ t

should be kept in briefcases, backpacks, or other carrying
cases that are not obvious.

Physical Security of Mobile Devices Do’s and Don’ts (continued)
Physical Security of Mobile
Devices
Do’s and Don’ts (continued)

• Do secure your mobile device when unattended.
• Do secure your mobile device when unattended. • D o

u n a t t e n d e d .

– Attach the mobile device with a security cable to something
– Attach the mobile device with a security cable to something

immovable or to a heavy piece of furniture when it is unattended (e.g. laptop).

– Hold onto your mobile device until the person in front of you
– Hold onto your mobile device until the person in front of you

has gone through the metal detector. Watch for your device to emerge from the screening equipment.

• Do record identifying information and mark your equipment. • D o

– Record the make, model, and serial number of the equipment and keep it in a separate location. Consider having the outside of the equipment case labeled with your agency’s contact information.
– Record the make, model, and serial number of the equipment
and keep it in a separate location. Consider having the outside
of the equipment case labeled with your agency’s contact
information.

• Do backup your files.
• Do backup your files. • D o
b a c k u p
y o u r
f i l e s .

– Make a backup of your files before every trip. In the event that your mobile device is lost or stolen, you will still have a copy of your data.
– Make a backup of your files before every trip. In the event that
your mobile device is lost or stolen, you will still have a copy of
your data.

About Encryption
About Encryption

What is encryption? • Encryption is the coding of data so that it cannot be read by anyone who does not know the password that decodes it. • Encryption garbles your data by using irreversible mathematical functions in order to make it nearly impossible to retrieve.
What is encryption?
• Encryption is the coding of data so that it • E n c r y p t i o n

About Encryption (continued)
About Encryption (continued)

vulnerable to accessibility, theft, loss, or damage. Protecting personal, confidential, and sensitive information is paramount and can easily be done through encryption. Even if your mobile device is stolen or accessed without your knowledge or permission, the encrypted information is useless to an outside user.

Encryption Requirements
Encryption Requirements

• Contractors are required to install a virus protection application and a 128 bit hard drive encryption application on all laptops or tablet PCs.
• Contractors are required to install a virus • C o n t r a c t o r s
a r e

t o
i n s t a l l
a
v i r u s
protection application and a 128 bit hard
drive encryption application on all
laptops or tablet PCs.

• Contractors may use Network funds to pay for these applications, but costs must be prorated according to Network full-time equivalent (FTE) percentages.

Reporting Mobile Device Theft, Loss, or Damage The following is a step-by-step process in the event that your mobile device is stolen, lost, or damaged:
Reporting Mobile Device Theft,
Loss, or Damage
The following is a step-by-step process in the event that
your mobile device is stolen, lost, or damaged:

Immediately contact your assigned Contract Manager and the appropriate law enforcement agency. – Relay any information from law enforcement
Immediately contact your assigned Contract
Manager and the appropriate law enforcement
agency.
– Relay any information from law enforcement – R e l a y

agencies, including police report number, to your Contract Manager. This information will be required for documentation of the incident. Your Contract Manager and other Network staff will notify appropriate State agencies about the incident and complete necessary reporting. Please make yourself available should your Contract Manager or other State staff need to contact you for more information.
